posts.name: Donald Williams
posts.cooked: Can someone point me to a source for a 5 port/3 way valve with 1/4" lines comparable to the 3/2 or 5/2 valves typically used in FRC? Thank you.

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked: First, 3-way valves are pretty uncommon in FRC, I think in part due to the requirement that the vent plug completely drain all pressure from the system (R813), which a closed center 3-way valve would violate, so you also need to be sure that you’re using a 3-way exhausting type valve (R804(G)).  The rule is a bit confusing as it doesn’t specifically say 3-way “solenoid” valve in R804(G) but rather “shutoff” valve, so a Q&A might be worthwhile if you’re looking at solenoid valves?  Note R804(C) allows both maximum of 1/8" NPT/BSPP/BSPT and maximum of 1/4" quick connect tubing.  I would look for SMC or Festo valves; the SMC SY3000 series is quite common in FRC, but I don’t know if they offer a 3-way valve variant in that series.

posts.name: Patrick Freivald
posts.cooked: Yeah, we used them a few years ago, and making them legally vent was quite the adventure.

posts.name: Stewart Riley
posts.cooked: Festo does in fact have 5/3 way solenoids with the middle position exhausted, which should be what you need. See this page on Festo’s website .

posts.name: Josh (he/him)
posts.cooked: It’s possible to make a circuit with a blocked center valve exhaust when the main pressure is vented utilizing a couple check valves and extra supply branches, but trying to maintain a middle position with a pneumatic actuator doesn’t come up all that often in FRC, and that’s the primary use case I can think of for such a circuit/valve choice.

posts.name: Donald Williams
posts.cooked: I agree. If the center port is blocked, then that line to the actuator needs to be directly routed, in an additional branch, to the manual pressure release valve that is opened at the end of the match.

posts.name: FrankJ
posts.cooked: Automation Direct has them. There is also a voucher for AD in the KOP
